text: Southerners love food. But can our restaurants survive a pandemic and a shutdown? This week on the Reckon Interview, restaurateur/chef @FrankStitt discusses how closures are hurting more than just the chefs and staff. And the steps he is taking to help.

Southerners love food. But can our restaurants survive a pandemic and a shutdown? @FrankStitt joins the Reckon Interview to discuss how the closures are hurting more than just the chefs and staff. And the steps he is taking to help. https://www.al.com/opinion/2020/05/frank-stitt-on-the-challenges-facing-restaurants-during-the-coronavirus-pandemic.html

Overall, we find that between March 14 and 28, state-level restaurant/bar limitations and non-essential business closures explain 4.4% and 8.5% of UI claims respectively, while the other policies did not increase UI claims (taking previously implemented policies as given).

Controlling for other policies matters: the effect of stay-at-home orders goes away after controlling for restaurant/bar limitations and non-essential business closures. And all individual policies have smaller effects once we control for the others. (Y-axes rescaled below)
Restaurant/bar limitations, non-essential business closures, and stay-at-home orders are associated with increases in searches for claiming UI...

Updated paper How do #shutdown policies affect unemployment during #COVID19? We now study six different policies: restaurant/bar limits, non-essential business closures, stay-at-home orders, large-gatherings bans, school closures, and emergency declarations. Thread
